Dgame.System.VertexRenderer



enum Target: int;
Declare which data is stored. Possible are Vertices, Colors or Texture coordinates.

None
Declare that the data consist of nothing relevant.

Vertex
Declare that the data consist of vertices.

Color
Declare that the data consist of colors.

TexCoords
Declare that the data consist of texture coordinates.

abstract class VertexRenderer;
Buffer is a wrapper for a static Vertex Array. It has nothing to do with the class VertexArray

Author:
rschuett

static void pointTo(Target trg, void* ptr = null, ubyte stride = 0, ubyte offset = 0);
Points to a specific Target.

See:
glVertexPointer

See:
glColorPointer

See:
glTexCoordPointer

See:
Target enum.

static void enableState(Target trg);
Enable a specific client state (with glEnableClientState) like GL_VERTEX_ARRAY, GL_COLOR_ARRAY, GL_TEXTURE_COORD_ARRAY with the corresponding Target.

static void enableAllStates();
Enable all client states

static void disableAllStates();
Disable all client states

static void disableState(Target trg);
Disable a specific client state (with glDisableClientState)

static void drawArrays(Shape.Type ptype, size_t count, size_t start = 0);
Draw Shapes of a specific type from the data which is addressed through 'pointTo'. It will use count vertices.

See:
pointTo

static void drawElements(Shape.Type ptype, size_t count, uint[] indices);
Draw Shapes of a specific type from the data which is addressed through 'pointTo'. It will use count vertices and indices for the correct index per vertex.

See:
pointTo

static void drawRangeElements(Shape.Type ptype, size_t count, uint[] indices, uint start = 0, uint end = 0);
Draw Shapes of a specific type from the data which is addressed through 'pointTo'. It will use count vertices and indices for the correct index per vertex.

Note:
If start or end are -1 or below, 0 and indices.length are used.

See:
pointTo
